title: Let's discuss AP itemization
body:
Now, after meme-ing the mage circle jerk let's actually discuss the "issue" with mages.
Which is the lack of diversity.

The items fulfill their job and mages are performing decently well but over the past few seasons AP itemization has become stale and extremely unsatisfying, especially compared to AD ones.

So, instead of whining over Mages being "weak", let's talk about the actual problem that is mage itemization:

__________________________________
Problem numero uno: Mages are forced into the same core build

Burst, Control, Assassin, every mage builds basically the same nowadays with {{item:3151}} {{item:3135}} {{item:3165}}  being extremely common, especially Morellonomicon just being "too good" as it just provides too much for its price and thus condemns other items to be mediocre and unsatisfying.
It's so good that I even started rushing it on Mordekaiser.
https://www2.pic-upload.de/img/34017251/Bildschirmfoto2017-10-02um11.05.07.png

https://www2.pic-upload.de/img/34017254/Bildschirmfoto2017-10-02um11.05.01.png

Which leads me to propose this fix:
Introduce more "core" rush items for mages that cater to their specific needs and niches.
Currently Morello is too good on every AP champion and just feels mandatory.

I suggest adding items similar to the ones in Black market brawlers, albeit with changed stats, that support certain AP play styles.

Pox Arcana for example being core on AoE and burst mages with Netherstride Grimoire being used on kite mages.
Make these items unique, making mages unable to get all of them so that they're not just getting stacked with enabling passive effects.
Most of these items should have mana, though CDR should be given out more sparingly, especially to burst-oriented builds.

_____________________________
Problem numero dos: We need more item variety in terms of Pen and battlemage itemization

With preseason mages are losing some mpen and unlike lethality and armour pen, MPEN is only present on three items {{item:3135}} {{item:3151}} {{item:3020}} 

And even then these items don't really seem to support certain niches but are rather mandatory.
I suggest we get more items building out of {{item:3136}}, providing certain end game items to fill niches like Tank-busting (%bonus Pen), squishy bursting (Flat pen) or sustained damage needs (Basically AP black cleaver)

Rylais too, has to be reworked imo to better support a sustained damage play style and I even suggest removing the permaslow for a windowed, more flexible and skillful form of CC on the item.
______________________
And numero tres: Some items need to be heavily retuned and their niche has to be explored better

{{item:3285}} {{item:3157}} {{item:3089}} {{item:3070}} 

Deathcap in particular needs a component item, or rather a "mini rabaddons"

Tear can use some rethinking too

_________________

And lastly, a rule of thumb, which I think should serve as the main rule when reworking Ap itemization:
#High AP values should not be matched with CDR

Sustained damage mages should opt actively into CDR and burst mages should prioritize big, juicy AP values.
There's a problem where EVERY mage gets 40% cdr, it devalues the importance of certain high impact spells and makes mage niches overlap.

AP items usually have CDR so that they are not so spiky (power in burst damage) as a 1 item purchase. Though as a design tradeoff, it means we need to give the item stats in other scaling categories (eg. CDR, %health damage), which leads to things like CDR creep. 

Agree that we need more choices in AP itemisation, however it's a reasonably big project and the designer needs to be careful they don't power creep the system, which is hard to do. 

I wouldn't say the system is all bad though, there is still some choice between Liandries/Ludens and Void/Zhonyas/Banshees/Hat are also all situational in 2nd/3rd slot too.

Would you agree that this is something that would have to be handled as another "pre-season makeover" like the runes reforged? As I agree that it will definitely require a major overhaul of the existing system.

That being said, those major power spikes are some of the reasons that players play mages to begin with, and I'm not entirely certain that it's inherently a bad thing either. Especially now, considering that the overall powerlevel of the game has gone up so much since when I started playing back in 2010. Fights are so much faster, and can end mere seconds after they start.

In fact, I just made a post replying to another player in this thread considering how the game has aged and how mages haven't quite aged as well as their AD counterparts. Here's a link if you'd like to check it out: https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/jHAgghMg-lets-discuss-ap-itemization?comment=0025000000000000

Long story short, I feel like the original concept of what a mage is was created in a world where the game was a lower paced system and mana costs and CD's were more meaningful, but as the game aged, and the pace of combat sped up, both players and riot have sought out ways to help mages adapt, and not all of which have been healthy for them. (like how players constantly seek ways to trivialize mana and cd's, and how riot has been lowering mana costs a lot since I started playing)

So in that respect I feel that's one reason why mage itemization lacks the luster it rightly deserves.

While many of the runes will be providing supplemental AP/damage, being forced to build a "defensive" item for optimal offense, feels a little lame. Basically this isn't an actual gameplay problem (it will still feel quite normal in terms of damage and cooldowns of course) but rather a gameplay fantasy problem.  I like the fantasy of a mage focusing purely on his offensive ability at the risk of being taken down when caught off guard.  Just allow me to build pure offense without losing out on offensive ability.

Obviously my playstyle isn't optimal every game, and I will adapt to those more defensive items when necessary (hello {{champion:56}}).  I just like being able to play a risky build when I want to.

AP assassin's need something that is unique to them that they can use best and that can't be shared with burst mages like annie for example.

"Or sustained damage needs (basically AP Black Cleaver)"

Two things. Number 1 - the original {{item:3001}} rework involved transforming it into basically an MR Sunfire Cape that reduced the MR of nearby targets with each burst, stacking a few times. So Riot has already tested a potential AP Black Cleaver and found issue with the idea.

Two - If sustained mages weren't already doing their jobs quite effectively, Riot would never have introduced {{item:3194}} . Tanks have been complaining that MR is too burst-oriented and does not do enough to prevent sustained magic damage for 4 seasons now. Sustained damage mages have enough power in their kits, they don't need a special item.

"Tank-busting (% bonus pen)" - Tanks are intended to absorb burst. They are intended to basically swallow a mage's rotation and come out alive. The mage's job is not to kill tanks, it's to kill everyone the tank is body-blocking for. Juggernauts and divers will usually only have one MR item ({{item:3156}} /{{item:3065}} ) and assassins are supposed to kill mages if they manage to close the gap. The mage has to peel for themselves and soften the assassin up at range in order to kill them. 

"More flat pen" - This would not affect mages nearly as much as it would affect AP assassins. Penetration over ability power favors champions with high base damage and low AP ratios, which are assassins. In particular, in a world where MR pen is powerful early and easy to stack, I foresee the return of assassin Elise. And we have a brand new Evelynn to contend with as well. AP assassins do need their own itemization update (not as much as divers) but let's not pretend that flat penetration is something that would be a 'mage' item. Flat penetration would give up AP. You'd see flat pen items that had 40 or 60 AP (like old Liandry's before Riot just decided to flat buff the item so _someone_ would buy it) and other passives to make up for them, and no mage would touch them because they value their ratios too much. 

High AP values should not be matched with CDR - They're not. And this is important. Battlemages currently have low AP high sustained damage CDR options in items like {{item:3100}} and{{item:3152}}  but they are **choosing** the higher AP options over those. That's not because the CDR options aren't good. They're amazing. Mages of all stripes just prefer raw damage output.
